Hi! Question: Is building a CMS site via the Design Manager still an viable option? Background: I am a designer proficient in front-end development (HTML, CSS, JS). A couple of years ago I built two client sites in HubSpot using the drag-and-drop template builder and custom CSS & JS. A few things have changed since I last used HubSpot to build a website… (I see the recommended method now, is command line / local development tools). A large part of the appeal of HubSpot CMS to me was the ability to build a fully fledged CMS / CRM driven site in a low-code environment, without having to enlist the services of a back-end developer. A potential new client project is coming up, so my question is: is this low-code approach still possible or not? Thanks in advance!
This is definitely still a viable option, it just comes somewhat short for fully customized themes.

a decentralized/headless integration -- I use headless wordpress for our marketing+commerce site with nextjs/typescript/node

and graphql-codegen packages to introspect and generate comprehensive enum/scalar/interface/type defs, the graphql AST, apollo type helpers (possible types), that kind of stuff

basically for a more optimized and fluid DX, really love when there's a graphql option because right now I'm using rest endpoints within Prisma resolvers to fetch for each individual resource on the server to create my own graphql endpoint to consume on the client
infographic of the big picture of our currently little ecosystem I made the other evening

so trying to tie together WPGraphQL mediated data with HubSpot data -- Gravity Forms Elite integration with WPGraphQL for scraping IP/user agent of users interacting with forms on the marketing/commerce site and then it is automatically persisted on submit to HubSpot, the wordpress mysql database, and the decentralized crm postgres database

but trying to tie it all together, maybe with a federated or stitched schema

I would also suggest leveraging a marketplace theme. This will give you a rough start that you can use the design manager to add custom modules to the existing theme. This way you can avoid the CLI and build from scratch. But if you want full control then you would need to use the CLI. The CLI isn't that daunting once you give it a try. This course is helpful in getting setup - <https://academy.HubSpot.com/lessons/CMS-themes-for-developers>
Try and find a theme that has reusable sections that you can "design" page layouts using reusable elements
